perturbation.original_text: If the solvency of the Society becomes impaired, you may be required to make an extra payment. The Board of Directors will determine the amount of any extra payment. It will be based on each member's fair share of the deficiency. You may make the extra payment by an equivalent reduction in benefits or by a payment in cash.
perturbation.changed_text: If the solvency of the Society becomes impaired, you are required to make an extra payment. The Board of Directors will determine the amount of any extra payment. It will be based on what the Board determines is a reasonable contribution. You must make the extra payment by an equivalent reduction in benefits.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'may be required' to 'are required' and 'fair share' to 'reasonable contribution' and eliminating 'or by a payment in cash' changes the nature of the assessment and payment of deficiency, creating ambiguity and potentially conflicting with regulations regarding fair and equitable treatment of members. Changing from 'you may make the extra payment by an equivalent reduction in benefits or by a payment in cash' to 'you must make the extra payment by an equivalent reduction in benefits' contradicts the original clause and potentially the law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Wisconsin Statutes, specifically concerning fraternal benefit societies and their solvency requirements.
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification removes the option for members to pay in cash, potentially contradicting the equitable treatment provisions expected of fraternal benefit societies under Wisconsin law regarding solvency and member contributions. The statute requires 'fair and equitable' treatment, which demanding only a reduction in benefits may not fulfill.

perturbation.original_text: Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, if any, will be credited as a dividend. Since we do not expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, it is not expected that any dividends will be credited.
perturbation.changed_text: Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus at our sole discretion. This contract's share will be determined by the Society. Since we do not expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, dividends may be allocated at the discretion of the board.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'This contract's share, if any, will be credited as a dividend' to 'This contract's share will be determined by the Society' implies that they do not necessarily have to credit it as a dividend, and replacing 'it is not expected that any dividends will be credited' with 'dividends may be allocated at the discretion of the board' makes the allocation of dividends uncertain and discretionary.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Wisconsin Statutes concerning fraternal benefit societies and dividend allocation.
perturbation.law_explanation: By making dividend allocation discretionary ('dividends may be allocated at the discretion of the board'), the modified text potentially violates the requirement of equitable distribution of divisible surplus among members, as interpreted under Wisconsin law. The statute mandates that any distribution must be fair and equitable.

perturbation.original_text: You may transfer ownership of this contract in accordance with our bylaws. Society membership rights and privileges cannot be transferred or assigned.
perturbation.changed_text: You may transfer ownership of this contract at our discretion. Society membership rights and privileges are transferrable at the discretion of the Board.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the 'in accordance with our bylaws' qualification and replacing it with 'at our discretion' and replacing 'cannot be transferred or assigned' with 'are transferrable at the discretion of the Board' alters the conditions for contract transfer, potentially creating uncertainty and conflicting with member rights.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Wisconsin Statutes related to fraternal benefit societies and member rights of assignment.
perturbation.law_explanation: The modification, by stating that contract transfer is 'at our discretion,' conflicts with the expected rights of members to transfer ownership subject to reasonable bylaws, as typically understood under Wisconsin law for fraternal benefit societies. The statute aims to protect member rights related to their contracts, and this change introduces uncertainty.
